name: Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder Due to Another Medical Condition

content.description: Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder (OCD) due to another medical condition is characterized by prominent obsessions, compulsions, or both, that are a direct physiological consequence of another medical disorder. The symptoms cause significant distress, are time-consuming, or impair functioning, and are not better explained by another mental disorder.
content.diagnostic_criteria: A. Prominent obsessions, compulsions, or both. B. Evidence from history, physical examination, or laboratory findings that the disturbance is the direct pathophysiological consequence of another medical condition. C. Symptoms are not better explained by another mental disorder. D. Symptoms do not occur exclusively during delirium. E. Symptoms cause clinically significant distress or impairment in social, occupational, or other important areas of functioning.
content.prevalence: Exact prevalence is unknown; depends on prevalence of associated medical conditions (e.g., Huntington's disease, epilepsy, brain injury).
content.age_of_onset: Varies according to onset of the underlying medical condition.
content.prognosis: Prognosis depends on reversibility of the underlying condition, severity of OCD symptoms, and timeliness of treatment. Symptoms may improve with treatment of the medical condition but often require concurrent psychiatric intervention.

circuitry: Lesions or dysfunction in cortico-striato-thalamo-cortical loops are implicated, similar to primary OCD.
neurochemistry: Neurotransmitter imbalances related to the underlying condition (e.g., dopamine excess in Huntington's disease, serotonin/glutamate changes post-stroke).
neurobiology.genetic_environmental: Genetic risk depends on the underlying medical disorder; environmental triggers may include brain injury, infections, or autoimmune responses.

history_psychosocial: Onset and temporal relationship of obsessions/compulsions to medical illness.
Nature of obsessions and compulsions, functional impact.
Medical history including neurological, infectious, autoimmune, and metabolic disorders.
medical_assessment: Laboratory workup relevant to suspected medical cause.
standardized_measures: Yale-Brown Obsessive Compulsive Scale (Y-BOCS) to quantify severity.
risk_stratification: Assess functional impairment and safety issues.
Evaluate for comorbid depression and suicidal ideation.
differential_diagnosis: Other psychiatric disorders secondary to medical conditions
evaluation.team_and_process: Collaborative care with neurology, psychiatry, and relevant specialties; integrate treatment for the underlying condition with OCD-focused interventions.

obsessions: Intrusive contamination fears following brain injury
Excessive doubts or harm fears after stroke
compulsions: Counting or ordering behaviors following tumor resection

severity_levels.mild: Symptoms present but manageable alongside medical treatment.
severity_levels.moderate: Symptoms interfere with daily function but partially controlled with intervention.
severity_levels.severe: Symptoms are disabling and impede management of the underlying medical condition.

impact_on_life.school_work: Absenteeism or inability to concentrate due to both medical illness and OCD symptoms.
impact_on_life.social: Withdrawal from social activities due to distress or rituals.
impact_on_life.medical: Poor adherence to medical treatments due to compulsions (e.g., excessive cleaning interfering with wound care).

comorbidities: Cognitive impairment depending on the underlying condition

psychotherapy: Exposure and Response Prevention (ERP) adapted to medical limitations.
Cognitive restructuring to address maladaptive beliefs.
medications: SSRIs at therapeutic doses (fluoxetine, sertraline, fluvoxamine, paroxetine, escitalopram).
Clomipramine for SSRI non-responders (monitor for anticholinergic and cardiac side effects).
Adjust doses for hepatic/renal impairment due to medical comorbidity.
neuromodulation: Consider rTMS or ECT in severe, refractory cases where safe given the medical condition.
lifestyle_interventions: Stress reduction techniques compatible with medical recovery.
care_coordination: Close communication between psychiatry and medical specialists.
Regular review of both psychiatric and medical treatment plans.

treatment_goals: Optimize management of the underlying medical condition.
Improve overall functioning and quality of life.
missed_diagnosis_factors: Assuming compulsive behaviors are coping mechanisms rather than pathological.
Overlooking OCD symptoms in the context of complex medical presentations.
overdiagnosis_factors: Misattributing normal adjustment behaviors after medical illness to OCD.
warning_signs: Rapid escalation of compulsions interfering with medical care
Refusal of necessary treatment due to contamination fears
self_help_strategies: Following structured exposure plans provided by clinicians.
Maintaining medical follow-ups while practicing ERP techniques.
Using relaxation and mindfulness exercises to manage anxiety.

childhood: Symptoms may emerge after infections (e.g., PANDAS); early evaluation is critical.
adolescence: Interference with schooling and peer relationships during medical recovery.
adulthood: Chronic illness management complicated by OCD rituals.

real_life_examples: A 45-year-old post-stroke patient develops severe checking rituals related to fears of leaving appliances on, delaying rehabilitation sessions.
A teenager recovering from autoimmune encephalitis develops contamination fears leading to refusal of physical therapy equipment.
content.when_to_seek_help: Seek help if obsessive-compulsive symptoms emerge or worsen after a medical illness and interfere with recovery or functioning.

positive_factors: Effective treatment of the underlying condition
Early initiation of ERP and medication
challenging_factors: Limited access to integrated medical-psychiatric care
